name: X-ray
description: Utilizes electromagnetic radiation to create images of bones and certain tissues inside the body.

name: Computed Tomography (CT)
description: Combines X-rays with computer technology to produce cross-sectional images of the body.

name: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
description: Uses magnetic fields and radio waves to generate detailed images of organs and tissues.

name: Ultrasound
description: Uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of internal organs and structures.

name: Positron Emission Tomography (PET)
description: Produces images of metabolic activity within the body, often used in oncology and neurology.

name: Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT)
description: Similar to PET, but uses different radioactive tracers to produce images of organ function.

name: Mammography
description: Specialized X-ray imaging used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis.

name: Fluoroscopy
description: Real-time X-ray imaging that allows visualization of moving structures within the body, often used during medical procedures.

name: Interventional Radiology
description: Minimally invasive procedures performed under imaging guidance (such as X-ray, CT, or ultrasound) to diagnose and treat diseases.

name: Nuclear Medicine
description: Uses small amounts of radioactive materials (radiotracers) to diagnose and treat a variety of diseases, such as cancer and heart disease.
